Parts of Speech.question: In 'The rising inflation is a concern for the RBI,' identify the function of 'rising'.
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Rising' modifies the noun 'inflation', acting as an adjective.

Parts of Speech.question: Which word is a verb in: 'The board will sanction the loan tomorrow'?
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Sanction' denotes the action to be performed by the subject.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the adjective in: 'The central bank maintained a hawkish stance.'
Identify the adverb: 'The fiscal deficit decreased significantly this year.'
In 'The CEO himself signed the documents,' 'himself' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: It is used for emphasis immediately after the noun it refers to.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the preposition: 'The merger is contingent upon regulatory approval.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Upon' is a fixed preposition used with 'contingent'.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the conjunction: 'He is talented yet humble.'
Which word is an interjection?
Identify the abstract noun: 'Integrity is the hallmark of a good leader.'
In 'This is a fast-moving market,' 'fast-moving' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: It describes the noun 'market' as a single unit.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the pronoun: 'Each of the candidates was interviewed.'
Identify the transitive verb: 'The company launched a new product.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Launched' requires an object ('product') to complete its meaning.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the preposition: 'Investors are bullish about the technology sector.'
In 'He speaks quite clearly,' 'quite' is a/an:
Identify the subordinating conjunction: 'Although the market is volatile, long-term prospects are good.'
Which word is an adjective? 'He provided a comprehensive report.'
Identify the collective noun: 'The jury reached a unanimous decision.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Jury' refers to a group acting as a single unit.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the auxiliary verb: 'The economy has recovered from the recession.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Has' helps form the present perfect tense.

Parts of Speech.question: In 'The very latest news is shocking,' 'very' is a/an:
Identify the interjection: 'Alas! The deal fell through.'
Identify the relative pronoun: 'The policy which was introduced last year is being reviewed.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Which' relates the clause to the noun 'policy'.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the correlative conjunction: 'Either the bank or the customer must bear the cost.'
Which word is a proper adjective?
Which of the following is the correct adverbial form?
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Fast' is both adjective and adverb; 'fastly' is non-standard.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the preposition: 'The interest rates are within the expected range.'
In 'The meeting lasted for three hours,' 'three' is a/an:
Identify the linking verb: 'The situation became critical.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Became' connects the subject to an adjective complement.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the possessive adjective: 'The bank updated its security protocols.'
Identify the adverb of frequency: 'The reports are reviewed quarterly.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Quarterly' tells how often the action happens.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the coordinating conjunction: 'The budget was tight, but the project succeeded.'
Which word is an interjection? 'Hurray! We won the contract.'
In 'The decision was made after long deliberation,' 'deliberation' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: It is a thing/process, acting as a noun.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the indefinite pronoun: 'Someone must have leaked the information.'
Identify the intransitive verb: 'The stock prices fell yesterday.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Fell' does not require a direct object.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the preposition: 'The company is moving towards sustainability.'
Identify the qualitative adjective: 'The project requires skilled workers.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Skilled' describes the quality of the workers.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the adverb of place: 'The head office is located nearby.'
Identify the conjunction: 'Neither the CEO nor the board was present.'
In 'The government's strength lies in unity,' 'strength' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: Denotes a quality/state, acting as a noun.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the demonstrative pronoun: 'These are the documents required.'
Identify the verb in the passive voice: 'The report was submitted on time.'
Identify the preposition: 'The growth is due to innovation.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Due to' is a compound preposition showing cause.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the comparative adjective: 'The new plan is more efficient than the old one.'
Identify the adverb of time: 'The data will be available shortly.'
Identify the interjection: 'Ouch! The interest rates hurt the borrowers.'
Identify the conjunction: 'Provided that the conditions are met, we will sign.'
In 'The quick expansion surprised many,' 'expansion' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: Refers to the process/result of expanding.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the possessive pronoun: 'This achievement is ours.'
Identify the verb in the past participle form: 'The broken glass was replaced.'
Identify the superlative adjective: 'This is the most profitable branch.'
Identify the adverb of manner: 'The software works seamlessly.'
In 'The firm’s resilience is admirable,' 'resilience' is a/an:
Identify the modal verb: 'We must comply with the regulations.'
Identify the quantitative adjective: 'The manager has some doubts.'
Identify the preposition: 'The office is located across the street.'
Identify the interrogative pronoun: 'Who authorized this transaction?'
Parts of Speech.explanation: Used to ask about the person.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the interjection: 'Whoops! I deleted the file.'
Identify the conjunction: 'While the economy is growing, inequalities persist.'
In 'The upcoming audit is mandatory,' 'upcoming' is a/an:
Identify the adverb of degree: 'The task is extremely difficult.'
In 'The bankruptcy was unexpected,' 'bankruptcy' is a/an:
Identify the phrasal verb: 'The meeting was called off.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: Verb + particle with a new meaning.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the reflexive pronoun: 'The team must organize themselves.'
Identify the preposition: 'The company operates in spite of challenges.'
Identify the adjective: 'The meticulous records saved the firm.'
Identify the adverb: 'The policy was implemented effectively.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: Tells how the policy was implemented.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the conjunction: 'As soon as the results are out, notify us.'
In 'The abundance of resources is key,' 'abundance' is a/an:
Identify the main verb: 'The analyst is preparing the forecast.'
Identify the interjection: 'Bingo! We found the error.'
Identify the indefinite pronoun: 'Everything is under control.'
Identify the adjective: 'The resilient economy survived the crash.'
Identify the adverb of degree: 'The news was quite surprising.'
Identify the preposition: 'The audit was conducted per guidelines.'
Identify the conjunction: 'In case of fire, use the stairs.'
In 'The persistence of the team paid off,' 'persistence' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: An abstract noun denoting a quality.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the verb: 'Investors should diversify their portfolios.'
In 'The strategic alliance was beneficial,' identify the adjectives.
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Strategic' modifies 'alliance', and 'beneficial' is a subject complement (predicate adjective).

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the adverb: 'The market fluctuates unpredictably.'
Identify the distributive pronoun: 'Neither of them was correct.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: Refers to members of a group individually.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the conjunction: 'So that we avoid delays, let's start now.'
In 'The innovation changed the industry,' 'innovation' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: A thing/idea, acting as a noun.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the verb: 'The regulator scrutinizes the filings.'
Identify the adjective: 'The lucrative deal was signed.'
Identify the adverb: 'The company is growing rapidly.'
Identify the preposition: 'The funds were distributed among the partners.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Among' shows relationship with more than two entities.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the pronoun: 'Few could understand the complex jargon.'
Identify the conjunction: 'Whether you like it or not, the policy stands.'
Identify the interjection: 'Ugh! These taxes are exhausting.'
In 'The stagnation of the sector is worrisome,' 'stagnation' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: Denotes a state of no growth.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the verb: 'The project will generate employment.'
Identify the adjective: 'The ambiguous language led to confusion.'
Identify the adverb: 'The meeting ended rather abruptly.'
Identify the pronoun: 'That is the reason for the delay.'
Identify the conjunction: 'Inasmuch as he is busy, he will help.'
In 'The recovery was swift,' 'recovery' is a/an:
Parts of Speech.explanation: Refers to the act/process of recovering.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the verb: 'The team collaborated on the task.'
Identify the adjective: 'The formidable opponent was respected.'
Identify the adverb: 'The data was analyzed thoroughly.'
Identify the interjection: 'Eek! There's a bug in the code.'
Identify the part of speech: 'The bank’s lending rates are **fixed**.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Fixed' acts as a complement describing the rates.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the gerund acting as a noun: 'Saving is essential for retirement.'
Identify the conjunction: 'He is poor yet honest.'
Identify the participle acting as an adjective: 'The hidden treasure was found.'
Identify the preposition: 'The office is beside the park.'
Identify the abstract noun: 'Knowledge is power.'
Identify the pronoun: 'Each of the participants was rewarded.'
Identify the modal auxiliary: 'He could have won the race.'
Identify the adjective: 'The exorbitant fees were criticized.'
Identify the relative pronoun: 'The person who called you is here.'
Identify the adverb of frequency: 'The system is updated daily.'
Identify the collective noun: 'The staff is very efficient.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: Refers to a group of employees.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the preposition: 'The signal travels through space.'
Identify the interrogative pronoun: 'Which is your favorite book?'
Identify the adjective of quantity: 'He has much experience.'
Identify the transitive verb: 'She wrote a letter.'
Identify the adverb: 'The wind blew fiercely.'
Identify the demonstrative pronoun: 'That was a great experience.'
Identify the adjective: 'The barren land was useless.'
Identify the adverb of manner: 'The project was handled skillfully.'
Identify the conjunction: 'Unless you study, you won't pass.'
Identify the proper noun: 'The Amazon is a vast river.'
Identify the auxiliary (helping) verb: 'The water is boiling.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Is' is the auxiliary verb used to form the present continuous tense.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the adverb of time: 'We will go tomorrow.'
Identify the possessive pronoun: 'This pen is mine.'
Identify the preposition: 'He is afraid of spiders.'
Identify the adjective: 'The tiny insect crawled.'
Identify the reflexive pronoun: 'The cat cleaned itself.'
Identify the adverb of place: 'Stay here until I return.'
Identify the auxiliary verb: 'She will arrive soon.'
Identify the adjective used as a noun: 'The brave deserve honor.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: Refers to a class of people.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the verb: 'He noticed the change.'
Identify the numeral adjective: 'He has two brothers.'
Identify the conjunction: 'He failed because he didn't study.'
Identify the adverb modifying an adjective: 'The soup is very hot.'
Identify the noun: 'Honesty is highly valued.'
Identify the linking verb: 'The cake tastes delicious.'
Identify the adjective: 'The ancient ruins were mysterious.'
Identify the emphatic pronoun: 'I myself will handle it.'
Identify the adverb: 'The exam was quite easy.'
Identify the finite verb: 'He runs every morning.'
Identify the preposition: 'The flight was delayed owing to bad weather.'
Identify the adjective: 'The fragile vase broke.'
Identify the conjunction: 'Neither he nor I am going.'
Identify the adverb: 'Why are you late?'
Identify the noun: 'The movement was peaceful.'
Identify the preposition: 'The bird flew over the house.'
Identify the adjective: 'It was a dull day.'
Identify the conjunction: 'He is slow but steady.'
Identify the interjection: 'Phew! That was close.'
Identify the adjective: 'The first chapter is interesting.'
Identify the reciprocal pronoun: 'They helped each other.'
Identify the adverb: 'The car moved very fast.'
Identify the conjunction: 'He stayed home since it was raining.'
Identify the noun: 'The architect designed the building.'
Identify the adjective: 'The ocean is vast.'
Identify the adverb: 'Consequently, the plan was changed.'
Identify the preposition: 'He was punished by the teacher.'
Identify the noun: 'His childhood was happy.'
Identify the interjection: 'Gosh! That’s expensive.'
Identify the adjective: 'The constant noise is annoying.'
Identify the adverb: 'The letter was written in haste.'
Identify the noun: 'The committee held a meeting.'
Identify the causative verb: 'He made me cry.'
Identify the adverb: 'He will definitely come.'
Identify the adjective: 'This is the best solution.'
Identify the noun: 'The scenery was breathtaking.'
Identify the adverb: 'However, he refused to help.'
Identify the preposition: 'Despite the rain, we went out.'
Identify the interjection: 'Hello! How are you?'
Identify the adjective: 'The very same person called again.'
Parts of Speech.explanation: 'Very' and 'Same' both act as emphatic adjectives.

Parts of Speech.question: Identify the adverb: 'Otherwise, you will be late.'
Identify the noun: 'A large amount of work remains.'
Identify the conjunction: 'He is rich, whereas his brother is poor.'
Identify the interjection: 'Yikes! That was scary.'

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Being a rainy day / (b) I stayed at home / (c) and watched a movie / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Dangling Participle: 'Being' lacks a proper subject. Correct: 'It being a rainy day'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Scarcely had I / (b) finished the work / (c) than the power went out / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Correlative Conjunction: 'Scarcely/Hardly' is followed by 'when', not 'than'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The number of candidates / (b) applying for the post / (c) have increased significantly / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Rule of 'The number of': 'The number of' takes a singular verb ('has'). 'A number of' takes plural.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I would rather / (b) you stayed here / (c) than went out tonight / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Subjunctive: After 'would rather + subject', the second conditional (V2) is correctly used. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Not only the manager / (b) but also the employees / (c) was involved in the fraud / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Proximity Rule: In 'Not only... but also', the verb agrees with the nearest subject ('employees'), so it should be 'were'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Work hard / (b) lest you / (c) may fail / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Rule of 'Lest': 'Lest' is always followed by 'should'. Correct: 'lest you should fail'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) She is one of the / (b) most brilliant students / (c) that has ever lived / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Relative Pronoun Agreement: 'That' refers to 'students' (plural), so the verb must be 'have', not 'has'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) It is high time / (b) the government / (c) takes strict action / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Rule of 'It is high time': Always followed by Simple Past (V2). Correct: 'took strict action'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Neither of the / (b) two candidates / (c) are eligible for the post / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Neither of' is followed by a plural noun but always takes a singular verb ('is').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I am looking forward / (b) to meeting you / (c) in the next summit / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Fixed Phrase: 'Look forward to' correctly takes a Gerund (V+ing). This is a common exam trap. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He is / (b) senior to / (c) me in the department / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Adjectives like senior, junior, prior, superior correctly take 'to'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The news of the / (b) recession / (c) were very disturbing / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'News' is an uncountable noun and always takes a singular verb ('was').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Unless you do not / (b) work hard, / (c) you will not pass / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Double Negative: 'Unless' itself is negative. It cannot be followed by 'not'. Correct: 'Unless you work hard'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) If I was you, / (b) I would not / (c) accept the offer / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Subjunctive Mood: For hypothetical situations, 'were' is used regardless of the subject. Correct: 'If I were you'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) More than one / (b) student / (c) were absent today / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Rule of 'More than one': It takes a singular noun and a singular verb ('was').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The cattle / (b) is grazing / (c) in the field / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Cattle' is a plural noun (collective) and takes a plural verb ('are').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Either he / (b) or I / (c) is going to the market / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Proximity Rule: With 'Either...or', the verb agrees with 'I', so it should be 'am'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Five miles / (b) are / (c) a long distance / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Specific units (distance, money, time) acting as a single unit take a singular verb ('is').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He died / (b) from / (c) cholera / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Fixed Preposition: One dies 'of' a disease, but 'from' an external cause (hunger/overwork).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The scenery / (b) of the Himalayas / (c) are very beautiful / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Scenery' is uncountable and takes a singular verb ('is').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The new scheme / (b) launched by the bank / (c) is much interesting / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: High-Yield Rule: Use 'Very' with Present Participles (V-ing) and 'Much' with Past Participles (V3). Correct: 'very interesting'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Each of / (b) the boys / (c) have their own book / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Each' takes a singular verb ('has') and singular pronoun ('his').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I have / (b) two / (c) brother-in-laws / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Pluralizing Nouns: The principal word is pluralized. Correct: 'brothers-in-law'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He works / (b) hardly / (c) to support his family / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Adverb Usage: 'Hardly' means scarcely. He works 'hard' (diligently).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Many a / (b) student / (c) have failed the test / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Rule of 'Many a': It takes a singular noun and a singular verb ('has').

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The committee / (b) were / (c) divided in their opinion / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Collective Nouns: When members are divided/acting individually, plural verb 'were' is correct. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He reached / (b) to the station / (c) just in time / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Transitive Verbs: 'Reach' takes no preposition before its object. Correct: 'reached the station'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) It is / (b) me who / (c) has implemented the changes / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Pronoun Case: After the 'Be' verb (It is/was), the subjective case is required. Correct: 'It is I who have...'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The reason why / (b) he failed is / (c) because he did not study / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Redundancy: 'Reason why' should be followed by 'that', not 'because'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) She is / (b) older / (c) than her sister / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Correct usage. 'Elder' is used without 'than' (e.g., my elder sister). 'Older' is correct for comparison. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I prefer / (b) swimming / (c) than walking / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Prefer' is always followed by 'to'. Correct: 'to walking'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He said / (b) that he / (c) will come tomorrow / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Sequence of Tenses: If the principal clause is in past tense, 'will' becomes 'would'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Unless you / (b) do not tell the truth / (c) you will be punished / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Repetitive rule check (ES013): 'Unless' cannot take 'not'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) These / (b) kind of books / (c) are very useful / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Kind' is singular. Correct: 'This kind of book' or 'These kinds of books'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The gold is / (b) a / (c) precious metal / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: No article is used before material nouns used in a general sense. Correct: 'Gold is...'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He is / (b) one of the / (c) cleverest boys / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'One of the' correctly takes plural noun and superlative degree. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Neither he / (b) nor his friends / (c) was present / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Proximity Rule: Nearest subject 'friends' is plural, so verb should be 'were'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I have / (b) an urgent / (c) work to do / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Work' is uncountable. Use 'a piece of urgent work' or just 'urgent work'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) No sooner did / (b) the thief see the police / (c) when he ran away / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Inversion: 'No sooner' takes 'than', not 'when'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) She is / (b) the most cleverest / (c) girl in the class / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Double Superlative: Correct: 'the cleverest'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) My brother / (b) as well as I / (c) are coming / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Rule of 'as well as': Verb agrees with the first subject ('My brother'), so it should be 'is'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is having / (c) a large family / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Stative Verbs: 'Have' used for possession is not used in continuous form. Correct: 'He has'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) One / (b) must do / (c) his duty / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Pronoun Agreement: 'One' must be followed by 'one's'. Correct: 'one's duty'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He is / (b) looking forward / (c) to see you / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Gerund Rule: 'To' here is a preposition. Correct: 'to seeing you'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He is / (b) sufficient / (c) intelligent / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Adverb modifying Adjective: Correct: 'sufficiently intelligent'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Between / (b) you and I, / (c) he is a thief / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Prepositional Case: After prepositions, objective case is used. Correct: 'Between you and me'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) This is / (b) the / (c) unique idea / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Absolute Adjectives: 'Unique' doesn't take 'the' or 'most'. Correct: 'a unique idea'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) very much taller / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Much taller' is standard. 'Very much taller' is emphatic but correct. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) reached home / (c) safely / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Correct adverbial usage. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Physics / (b) are / (c) a difficult subject / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Nouns ending in 's' (subjects) are singular. Correct: 'is'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The patient / (b) died / (c) before the doctor arrived / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Earlier past action must be in Past Perfect. Correct: 'had died'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is used to / (c) smoke / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Is used to' (habit) takes a gerund. Correct: 'to smoking'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) told him / (c) that I am busy / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Sequence of Tense: 'am' becomes 'was'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Let / (b) he / (c) go there / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: After 'Let', objective case is used. Correct: 'him'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Neither Ram / (b) nor his parents / (c) was present / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Proximity rule (repeat check ES037): 'parents' is plural, so 'were'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) shall / (c) call you when the train will arrive / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Future Condition: In the time clause ('when'), simple present is used. Correct: 'the train arrives'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The analyst / (b) behaves / (c) as if he is a billionaire / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Subjunctive Mood: 'As if' requires 'were' for hypothetical present situations regardless of the subject.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Both / (b) Ram as well as Shyam / (c) are coming / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Both' is followed by 'and', not 'as well as'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) an university student / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: 'University' starts with a consonant sound ('yoo'). Correct: 'a university student'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) She / (b) is / (c) a M.A. / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: 'M.A.' starts with a vowel sound ('em'). Correct: 'an M.A.'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) know / (c) how to swim / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Correct use of infinitive with 'how to'. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) more superior to me / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Superior' is an absolute comparative and doesn't take 'more'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The rich / (b) is / (c) not always happy / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Adjectives used as Nouns: 'The rich' refers to a class (plural). Correct: 'are'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) have / (c) no house to live / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Dangling Preposition: Correct: 'to live in'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) works / (c) at office / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: Specific place of work. Correct: 'in the office' or 'at the office'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) too happy / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Too' has a negative connotation (more than enough). Use 'very happy'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) This / (b) is / (c) more preferable than that / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Preferable' takes 'to' and does not take 'more'. Correct: 'preferable to'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) a honest man / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: Silent 'h'. Correct: 'an honest man'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) shall / (c) go there unless you will not call me / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Double rule check (ES013): 'Unless' + Present tense + No 'not'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) One of / (b) the / (c) boy is playing / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'One of' always takes a plural noun. Correct: 'boys'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) and / (c) myself went there / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Pronoun Case: Reflexive pronoun cannot be a subject. Correct: 'He and I'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) the tallest of the two / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Comparison Rule: For two people, comparative degree is used. Correct: 'the taller of the two'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) am / (c) having two brothers / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Stative verb possession rule (repeat check ES042).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) older to me / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Older' takes 'than'. 'Elder' takes 'to'. Correct: 'older than me'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The sun / (b) rises / (c) in east / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: Directions take 'the'. Correct: 'in the east'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) go / (c) to the school daily / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Omission of Article: No 'the' if the place is used for its primary purpose (study). Correct: 'to school'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) an European / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: 'European' starts with 'y' sound. Correct: 'a European'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) have / (c) many works to do / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Work' rule (repeat check ES038): Uncountable noun.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) works / (c) very hardly / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Adverb rule (repeat check ES024).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) It / (b) is / (c) a best book / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: Superlative takes 'the'. Correct: 'the best book'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Tell / (b) me / (c) the truth / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Correct usage. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) in the jail / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Omission of Article: If used as a prisoner. Correct: 'in jail'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) like / (c) these kind of books / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Singular/Plural rule (repeat check ES034).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) taller than me / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Comparison Case: Pronoun after 'than' should be in subjective case. Correct: 'taller than I (am)'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He is / (b) incompetent / (c) at doing his job / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Fixed Preposition: 'Incompetent at' is the standard idiomatic usage. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) I / (b) saw / (c) an one-eyed man / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Article Usage: 'One' starts with 'w' sound. Correct: 'a one-eyed man'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) said / (c) that the sun rose in the east / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Universal Truth: Does not change tense. Correct: 'rises'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) One / (b) of my / (c) book is lost / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'One of' rule (repeat check ES070).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) is / (c) senior than me / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Senior' rule (repeat check ES011).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) She / (b) is / (c) married with a doctor / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Fixed Preposition: 'Married to'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) This / (b) is / (c) the most unique dress / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Unique' absolute rule (repeat check ES047).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Between / (b) you and / (c) me, he is wrong / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Correct objective case after preposition. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) prefers / (c) tea to coffee / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Correct 'prefer to' usage. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) Each / (b) of the / (c) student has a pen / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Noun after 'of' must be plural. Correct: 'students'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) The news / (b) are / (c) very interesting / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Uncountable noun rule (repeat check ES012).

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) My / (b) father / (c) gave me many advices / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: 'Advice' is uncountable. Correct: 'many pieces of advice' or 'much advice'.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He is / (b) angry / (c) with my behavior / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Fixed Preposition: Angry 'with' a person, but angry 'at' a behavior/thing.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) She is / (b) the cleverer / (c) of the two sisters / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: The + Comparative: Correct when comparing specific two. No error.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He / (b) reached / (c) home lately / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Adverb Usage: 'Lately' means recently. Use 'late' for time.

Error Spotting.question: Find the error: (a) He is / (b) as clever / (c) than his brother / (d) No error.
Error Spotting.explanation: Comparison Rule: 'As...as' for equality. Correct: 'as clever as'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The CEO, along with the directors, are attending the conference.
options: along with the directors, is attending
along with the directors, were attending
as well as the directors, are attending
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Rule of Proximity: When a subject is joined by 'along with' or 'as well as', the verb agrees with the first subject ('CEO').

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: If I was the Governor of RBI, I would lower the repo rate.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Subjunctive Mood: Use 'were' for hypothetical or unreal conditions regardless of the subject.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Scarcely had the session started than the members began to protest.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Inversion Pair: 'Scarcely/Hardly' must be paired with 'when'. 'No sooner' is paired with 'than'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is one of the players who has been selected for the national team.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Relative Pronoun Agreement: 'Who' refers to 'players' (plural), so the verb must be 'have'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I am used to work late at the office.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Habitual 'Used to': When 'used to' is preceded by a 'be' verb (am, is, are), it takes a Gerund (V+ing).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Neither the reports nor the **data is** accurate.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Data' is the plural of 'Datum' and requires 'are'. Verb agrees with nearest subject ('data').

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The news of his resignation were a shock to everyone.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'News' is an uncountable noun and always takes a singular verb.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is the most cleverest girl in the batch.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Double Superlative: Avoid using 'most' with an adjective that already has '-est'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Hardly I had reached the station when the train left.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Inversion: When a sentence starts with a negative adverb (Hardly), the verb must come before the subject.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: It is high time we start preparing for the Mains.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: After 'It is high time', the simple past tense (V2) is mandatory.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The number of employees have decreased this year.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'The number of' is singular; 'A number of' is plural.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is more intelligent than any boy in his class.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Comparison Rule: When comparing a person to their own group, use 'any other' to exclude that person from the group.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I would rather you go now.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: When 'would rather' is followed by a subject, use the subjunctive past (V2).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The climate of Pune is **better than Mumbai**.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Parallelism: You must compare climate to climate. 'That of' correctly replaces 'the climate of'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Lest you should not fail, work hard.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Lest' is inherently negative; it should not be followed by 'not'. It is always paired with 'should'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I look forward to hear from you.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Look forward to' is a phrasal verb where 'to' is a preposition, requiring a Gerund (V+ing).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Each of the three candidates are eligible.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Each' is distributive and always takes a singular verb.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is the taller of all the students in the class.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: When comparing more than two, use the superlative degree ('tallest').

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: They were discussed about the matter.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Transitive Verbs: 'Discuss' does not take the preposition 'about'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Unless you do not work hard, you will fail.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Double Negative: 'Unless' is already negative. Correct: 'Unless you work'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Being a hot day, I stayed indoors.
options: As it being a hot day
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Dangling Participle: 'Being' needs a proper subject ('It') to avoid suggesting 'I' was the hot day.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The quality of the oranges were not good.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: The subject is 'quality' (singular), not 'oranges'. Hence, 'was'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Not only he but also his friends has arrived.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Rule of Proximity: Verb agrees with 'friends' (plural).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Either the bank or the customers is responsible.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Rule of Proximity: Verb agrees with 'customers'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Supposing if he fails, what will he do?
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Redundancy: 'Supposing' and 'if' mean the same thing; use only one.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He died with cholera.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Fixed Preposition: One dies 'of' a disease.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is as smart if not smarter than her sister.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Parallelism: 'As smart' must be completed with 'as' before the second part of the comparison.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I have seen him yesterday.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Simple Past: Use V2 with definite past time markers like 'yesterday'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is married with a banker.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Fixed Preposition: 'Married to'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The committee has divided on the issue.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Collective Noun: Use plural verb when members are acting individually or are in disagreement.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He behaves as if he were a millionaire.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Subjunctive: Correct as written. 'Were' is used for imaginary positions.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: No sooner the sun rose than the fog disappeared.
options: No sooner had the sun risen
No sooner did the sun rise
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Inversion: After 'No sooner', use 'had + subject + V3' or 'did + subject + V1'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He has no house to live.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Dangling Preposition: An infinitive following a noun often requires a preposition.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: If I had money, I would have helped him.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Third Conditional: 'If + had + V3' corresponds with 'would have + V3'. Here 'had' is the V3 of 'have'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Ramesh is senior than all other colleagues.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Latin Adjectives: Senior, junior, superior always take 'to'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She prefers coffee over tea.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Idiomatic usage: 'Prefer... to'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The reason why he is absent is because he is ill.
options: is due to he is ill
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Redundancy: 'Reason why' should be followed by 'that'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: One should keep his promises.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Pronoun Agreement: 'One' must be followed by 'one's'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is more better than his brother.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Double Comparative: 'More better' is wrong; 'much better' is acceptable for emphasis.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The principal and secretary were present.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Article Rule: If the article 'the' is used only once, it refers to one person holding both posts. Thus, the verb should be singular ('was').

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He works very hardly.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Hard' is an adverb meaning 'with effort'. 'Hardly' means 'scarcely'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I didn't knew the answer.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Auxiliary Rule: 'Do/did' is always followed by the base form (V1).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Between you and I, she is a liar.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Prepositional Case: After 'Between', use the objective case ('me').

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Each boy and each girl were given a pen.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Distributive Rule: Subjects joined by 'and' but preceded by 'each/every' take a singular verb.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He entered into the classroom silently.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Transitive Verbs: 'Enter' (place) takes no preposition. (Enter into an agreement is different).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He has been working here since five years.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'For' is used for a duration; 'Since' for a point in time.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I would help him if he had come to me.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Third Conditional consistency: 'would have helped'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is so weak that he cannot walk.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Both structures 'so...that' and 'too...to' are grammatically correct.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is the elder of the two sisters.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Elder' is used within family comparisons of two.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The ship was drowned in the ocean.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Diction: 'Drown' is for living things; 'Sink' is for inanimate objects.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He said that he will call later.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Sequence of Tense: Past reporting verb requires 'would' in the clause.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Every student must submit their project.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Pronoun Agreement: 'Every' is singular, so 'their' is informally okay but grammatically 'his or her' is preferred.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Many a man has lost their lives in the war.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Many a' takes singular noun, verb, and pronoun.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The inflation rate is quite higher than expected.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Quite' is generally used with positive degrees. 'Much' is used with comparative degrees.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I have completed the work two hours ago.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Simple Past (V2) is required with specific past time markers ('ago').

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He recommended me to buy this book.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Recommend' doesn't take 'person + to-infinitive'. It takes a 'that' clause or gerund.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: What is the time in your watch?
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Idiomatic usage: 'By your watch'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I, you and he are friends.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Pronoun Order: For positive sentences, the order is 2-3-1 (You, He, I).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He didn't give me some money.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Negative/Interrogative sentences generally take 'any' instead of 'some'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Select the grammatically preferred version for formal reports:
options: The data is suggesting a recovery.
The data are suggesting a recovery.
The datas are suggesting a recovery.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: In formal/academic English (standard for RBI/SEBI), 'data' is the plural of 'datum' and takes a plural verb.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He has no other choice but to resign.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'No other' is followed by 'than'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I want to know where does he live.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Indirect Question: The word order should be Subject + Verb, not Auxiliary + Subject.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is as tall, if not taller than her mother.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Parallelism Rule (repeat check MEI027).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is very older than me.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Very' is for positive degree; 'Much' is for comparative degree.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The furniture in the office are expensive.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Furniture' is an uncountable noun and takes a singular verb.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: No one can prevent me to go there.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Fixed Preposition: 'Prevent from' + Gerund.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is lacking of courage.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Verb vs Adjective: 'Lacking' (adjective) takes 'in'; 'Lacks' (verb) takes no preposition.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The train had left before I reached the station.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Past Perfect + Simple Past structure is correct.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The candidate is **too intelligent to solve** the case study.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Logic Error: 'Too...to' implies a negative result (cannot solve). 'Intelligent enough' is the correct positive structure.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I, you and he have done the mistake.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Pronoun Order for negative acts/confessions: 1-2-3 (I, You, He).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The price of these items are varying.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Subject is 'price' (singular).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Who is the tallest of the two?
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Comparative degree is used for two people.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I am looking forward to meet you.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Gerund rule check (repeat check MEI016).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He behaved as though he was a king.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Subjunctive mood check (repeat check MEI031).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He didn't denied the charges.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Auxiliary rule check (repeat check MEI042).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is elder than her friend.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Elder' is only for blood relations.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Neither of them were present.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'Neither of' takes a singular verb.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Hardly had I begun the work than the guests arrived.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Hardly...when rule check (repeat check MEI003).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I have no money for giving you.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Infinitive of purpose: 'To give you'.

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The news were reported yesterday.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: 'News' is singular check (repeat check MEI007).

Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is more wiser than his brother.
Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Double comparative check (repeat check MEI039).
Transitive rule check (repeat check MEI045).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She entered into the room.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Latin adjective check (repeat check MEI035).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is junior than me.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Simple Past check (repeat check MEI028).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: I have seen him yesterday.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Fixed preposition check (repeat check MEI029).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is married with him.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: For/Since check (repeat check MEI046).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He has been here since two years.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Distributive check (repeat check MEI017).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Each of the boys are smart.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Comparative of two check (repeat check MEI072).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She is the best of the two.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Double negative check (repeat check MEI020).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Unless you do not tell the truth.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Idiom check (repeat check MEI036).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: She prefers tea than coffee.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Dangling preposition check (repeat check MEI064).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Give me a pen to write.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Subject-Verb check (repeat check MEI022).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The quality of mangoes were good.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Collective noun check (repeat check MEI030).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The jury was divided.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Diction check (repeat check MEI050).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The boat was drowned.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Inversion check (repeat check MEI009).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: Hardly she had entered.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Sequence check (repeat check MEI051).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He said he will help.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Article rule check (repeat check MEI040).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The director and secretary were present.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Uncountable check (repeat check MEI065).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: The furniture are old.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: Relative Pronoun check (repeat check MEI004).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: He is one of the men who has won.

Mixed Error & Improvement.explanation: High Time check (repeat check MEI010).
Mixed Error & Improvement.question: It is high time we leave.

Tenses.question: The RBI _____ the new monetary policy tomorrow at 10:00 AM.
Tenses.explanation: Simple Present is used to denote fixed future programs or official schedules.

Tenses.question: If the government _____ the taxes earlier, the deficit would have been manageable.
Tenses.explanation: Third Conditional: 'If + Past Perfect (had+V3)' is required to match the result clause 'would have + V3'.

Tenses.question: The auditors _____ the accounts since morning but have found no errors yet.
Tenses.explanation: Present Perfect Continuous is used for an action that started in the past and is still continuing.

Tenses.question: By the time the regulator intervened, the company _____ most of its assets.
Tenses.explanation: Past Perfect is used for the earlier of two past actions (selling assets happened before the intervention).

Tenses.question: I wish I _____ the market volatility before investing my savings.
Tenses.explanation: Wish expressing a past regret requires the Past Perfect tense.

Tenses.question: It is high time we _____ our investment strategy to minimize risks.
Tenses.explanation: After 'It is high time', the simple past tense (V2) is mandatory.

Tenses.question: By the end of this month, the bank _____ ten years of operations in this city.
Tenses.explanation: Future Perfect is used for an action that will be completed by a specific point in the future.

Tenses.question: He behaved as if he _____ the owner of the firm.
Tenses.explanation: Subjunctive mood: 'as if' takes 'were' for hypothetical or unreal present situations.

Tenses.question: No sooner _____ the meeting begun than the power went off.
Tenses.explanation: Inversion: 'No sooner' is followed by 'had + subject + V3' (begun).

Tenses.question: The project _____ successful if the team had worked in coordination.
Tenses.explanation: Third Conditional: 'would have + V3' matches 'If + had + V3'.

Tenses.question: They _____ for the bus when the accident occurred.
Tenses.explanation: Past Continuous is used for an ongoing past action interrupted by another action (Simple Past).

Tenses.question: I _____ him only once since he moved to Mumbai.
Tenses.explanation: Present Perfect is used with 'since' to show an action occurring from a point in the past to the present.

Tenses.question: Hardly _____ I reached the station when the train whistled.
Tenses.explanation: Inversion: 'Hardly' is followed by 'had + subject + V3'.

Tenses.question: She _____ for the company for five years before she got promoted.
Tenses.explanation: Past Perfect Continuous shows duration leading up to another point in the past.

Tenses.question: If you _____ the report on time, the manager wouldn't have been angry.
The train _____ at 8:00 PM tonight.
Tenses.explanation: Scheduled future action rule (repeat check TEN001).

Tenses.question: I _____ the work before he arrived.
Tenses.explanation: Past Perfect for the first of two past actions.

Tenses.question: She _____ not come yet.
Tenses.explanation: 'Yet' is used with Present Perfect in negative context.

Tenses.question: We _____ for him for two hours when he finally called.
If I _____ a bird, I would fly.
The analyst claimed that the stock _____ its resistance level.
Tenses.explanation: Indirect Speech: Past reporting verb requires Past Perfect for the action.

Tenses.question: By the end of the year, inflation _____ to a single digit.
Unless the regulator _____ the norms, the crisis will deepen.
Tenses.explanation: Conditional Clause: 'Unless/If' part stays in Simple Present for Future result.

Tenses.question: He _____ not seen the report yet.
While I _____ in the office, the news broke.
I _____ to the bank every Monday.
She _____ the agreement before reading the clauses.
Tenses.explanation: Past Perfect for earlier past action.

Tenses.question: They _____ the project by next week.
It is time you _____ hard for the examination.
The water _____ at 100 degrees Celsius.
He _____ here since the company was established.
Tenses.explanation: Present Perfect for state continuing from past.

Tenses.question: If I _____ you, I would accept the promotion.
The bell _____ before I reached the classroom.
I _____ for the exam for two months by the end of July.
Tenses.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous: Action ongoing up to a future time.

Tenses.question: She _____ a novel these days.
Tenses.explanation: Temporary action in progress → Present Continuous.

Tenses.question: The sun _____ in the west.
By 10 PM tonight, I _____ my dinner.
He _____ for the interview last Friday.
They _____ to the office when it started raining.
She _____ her keys; she cannot enter the house.
Tenses.explanation: Present Perfect for action with present relevance.

Tenses.question: If he _____ faster, he would catch the train.
Tenses.explanation: Second Conditional: 'If + V2' paired with 'would + V1'.

Tenses.question: The Governor _____ the bank tomorrow.
Hardly _____ the match started when it began to hail.
She _____ her homework before she went to bed.
They _____ in this house for ten years now.
I _____ a loud noise last night.
The train _____ before we reached the station.
By this time tomorrow, he _____ in London.
I wish I _____ more money.
She _____ when I called her.
If the audit team _____ the error, the loss could have been avoided.
No sooner _____ I seen the boss than I started working.
He behaves as if he _____ everything.
The prices _____ significantly this year.
Tenses.explanation: Present Perfect for indefinite time in current year.

Tenses.question: I _____ the report by Monday.
She said she _____ the news already.
While we _____ for the bus, it started to snow.
The Earth _____ around the Sun.
It is high time you _____ home.
He _____ not come back yet.
If she _____ hard, she will succeed.
The patient _____ before the doctor arrived.
By next year, he _____ in the bank for twenty years.
I _____ him only yesterday.
She _____ her breakfast an hour ago.
The climate of India _____ warmer.
They _____ the movie already.
He _____ not finished his homework yet.
If I _____ a million dollars, I would buy a car.
The train _____ at 6 AM tomorrow.
I _____ for the manager since 10 AM.
She _____ cooking dinner when I entered.
They _____ to Mumbai last week.
By next week, we _____ the results.
I _____ the work before he came.
She _____ never seen such a beautiful sight.
He _____ for the test these days.
The sun _____ at 6 PM yesterday.
We _____ here since morning.
If it _____ tomorrow, we will stay home.
I _____ my dinner just now.
He _____ in London for five years before moving to Paris.
Tenses.explanation: Past Perfect for state before another past action.

Tenses.question: The meeting _____ by the time I arrived.
She _____ English for two years by 2026.
He _____ not replied to my email yet.
If I _____ you, I would go.
The Earth _____ around its axis.
I _____ him last week.
They _____ for the result for a long time.
By the time you get home, I _____ the dinner.
He _____ to the gym every morning.
I _____ the book before you asked.
It is time we _____ some action.
She _____ not reached home yet.
If I _____ his address, I would have visited him.
The train _____ at 10 PM tonight.
They _____ playing cricket since morning.
He _____ not seen the movie yet.
By next month, I _____ here for a year.
She _____ her keys an hour ago.
